claim: Parents share more genes with their child than siblings do.

supporting.text: Parents pass on 50% of their genes to each child, while siblings share on average 50% of their genes with each other, making the genetic relationship equal.

attacks.text: Parents pass on 50% of their genes to each child, while siblings share on average 50% of their genes with each other, making the genetic relationship equal.
The 50% shared between siblings is an average, meaning some siblings share more or less than 50%, while parents always pass exactly 50% to each child.
Even though the average is 50%, the variance in sibling genetic sharing is typically small, making the difference practically negligible in most cases.
Mitochondrial DNA and Y-chromosomes are inherited exclusively from one parent, creating additional genetic sharing asymmetry not captured by the 50% average.
These exceptions (mitochondrial DNA and Y-chromosomes) represent a tiny fraction of the genome, so their impact on overall genetic similarity is minimal.

supporting.text: Due to recombination during meiosis, siblings may share slightly more or less than 50% of their genes, but the average remains approximately 50%, the same as parent-child relationships.

attacks.text: Due to recombination during meiosis, siblings may share slightly more or less than 50% of their genes, but the average remains approximately 50%, the same as parent-child relationships.
Parent-child relationships always share exactly 50% of genes, while sibling-sibling relationships can vary significantly due to independent assortment and recombination.
The variation in gene sharing between siblings is typically small, and the average remains very close to 50%, making the practical difference negligible in most cases.
Mitochondrial DNA is inherited exclusively from the mother, meaning parent-child relationships share additional genetic material not accounted for in sibling comparisons.
Mitochondrial DNA constitutes a tiny fraction of the total genome, so its contribution to overall genetic similarity is minimal.

supporting.text: A parent shares exactly 50% of their genes with their child, whereas siblings share 50% on average, but this can vary due to random assortment of alleles.

attacks.text: A parent shares exactly 50% of their genes with their child, whereas siblings share 50% on average, but this can vary due to random assortment of alleles.
Identical twins share 100% of their genes, which is more than the 50% shared between parent and child.
Identical twins are a rare exception and do not represent the general case of sibling genetic similarity.
In cases of consanguinity (e.g., sibling parents), the child may share more than 50% of genes with a parent due to increased homozygosity.
Consanguineous relationships are uncommon in most populations and are ethically discouraged, making them statistically irrelevant to the general claim.

supporting.text: Genetically, a parent and child are directly related by 50% shared DNA, while siblings share 50% on average, making the relationships quantitatively equivalent in terms of gene sharing.

attacks.text: Genetically, a parent and child are directly related by 50% shared DNA, while siblings share 50% on average, making the relationships quantitatively equivalent in terms of gene sharing.
The 50% shared DNA between siblings is an average, with actual values ranging from 0% to 100% due to random recombination, whereas parent-child sharing is always exactly 50%.
Even with variation, the vast majority of sibling pairs share close to 50% DNA, making the average a reliable approximation for most practical purposes.
Parent-child relationships share mitochondrial DNA (or Y-chromosome in father-son cases), which siblings do not necessarily share, adding to genetic similarity beyond autosomal DNA.
Mitochondrial and Y-chromosome DNA constitute a tiny fraction of the genome, so their contribution to overall genetic similarity is negligible.
